data.title: One Womanâ€™s Mission to Rewrite Nazi History on Wikipedia
data.meta_description: Ksenia Coffmanâ€™s fellow editors have called her a vandal and a McCarthyist. She just wants them to stop glorifying fascistsâ€”and start citing better sources.
data.text:
When Ksenia Coffman started editing Wikipedia, she was like a tourist in Buenos Aires in the 1950s. She came to learn the tango, admire the architecture, sip matÃ©. She didnâ€™t know there was a Nazi problem. But Coffman, who was born in Soviet-era Russia and lives in Silicon Valley, is an intensely observant traveler. As she link-hopped through articles about the Second World War, one of her favorite subjects, she saw what seemed like a concerted effort to look the other way about Germanyâ€™s wartime atrocities.

Coffman canâ€™t recall exactly when her concern set in. Maybe it was when she read the article about the SS, the Nazi Partyâ€™s paramilitary, which included images that felt to her like glamour shotsâ€”action-man officers admiring maps, going on parade, all sorts of â€œvery visually disturbingâ€ stuff. Or maybe it was when she clicked through some of the pages about German tank gunners, flying aces, and medal winners. There were hundreds of them, and the menâ€™s impressive kill counts and youthful derring-do always seemed to exist outside the genocidal Nazi cause. What was going on here? Wikipedia was supposed to be all about consensus. Wasnâ€™t there consensus on, you know, Hitler?

A typical person might have thought, Something is wrong on the internet again. What a bummer. Next tab. But Coffman is the person who finishes the thousand-page Holocaust novel. Whatever she chooses to spend her time onâ€”powerlifting, fragrance collecting, denazificationâ€”she approaches the assignment like a straight-A student. You can time-travel back and watch her begin. Wikipedia never forgets; it keeps a permanent public record of every change an editor makes.

In early November 2015, you will find K.e.coffman in â€œ20 July plot,â€ an article about the failed plan by German officers to assassinate Hitler. A sentence has jumped out at her. It says that some of the conspirators came to see the plot as â€œa grand, if futile gestureâ€ that would save â€œthe honour of themselves, their families, the army and Germany.â€ The claim isnâ€™t supported by any sources. Itâ€™s conjecture, hearsay. And to her it seems strangely flattering.

Coffman navigates over to the Wikipedia article about one of the conspiratorsâ€”Arthur Nebe, a high-ranking member of the SS. Apart from his role in the plot, Nebeâ€™s main claim to notability is that he came up with the idea of turning vans into mobile gas chambers by piping in exhaust fumes. The article acknowledges both of these facts, along with the detail that Nebe tested his system on the mentally ill. But it also says that he worked to â€œreduce the atrocities committed,â€ going so far as to give his bloodthirsty superiors inflated death totals.

Coffman will recall that she feels â€œtotally disoriented.â€ She cannot believe that an innovator in mass murder would have tried to protect the Jews and other supposed subhumans his troops rounded up. She checks the footnotes. The claim is attributed to War of Extermination, a compendium of academic essays originally published in 1995.

Coffman knows the book is legit, because she happens to have a copy on loan from the library. When she goes to the cited page, she finds a paragraph that appears to confirm all the Wikipedia articleâ€™s wild claims. But then she reads the first sentence of the next paragraph: â€œThis is, of course, nonsense.â€

The level of bad faith is eye-opening for Coffman. She is â€œvery appalled.â€ She sees that her confidence in Wikipedia was â€œvery much misplaced.â€ All it takes to warp historical memory, she realizes, is something this small, achievable for almost anyone with a keyboard. â€œSo few people can have so much impact, itâ€™s a little scary,â€ she says. She begins to turn a more critical eye to what she sees on Wikipedia. Especially the footnotes.

In a long spree of edits, Coffman cleans up the two articles. She goes to the Talk page for â€œ20 July plot,â€ where editors debate changes to the main article. She copy-pastes the language about the grand, futile gesture. â€œI would like to remove this part,â€ she writes. â€œThoughts? Objections?â€ Another editor voices support. With a click, the paragraph is gone.

In the Nebe article, Coffman adds a â€œ[citation needed]â€ tag to the flagrantly false claim. She identifies two more dubious sourcesâ€”one misleadingly quoted, one potentially invented. She checks out a book called The SS: Alibi of a Nation to make sure. Over and over again, she reworks Nebeâ€™s legacy: At first, itâ€™s that some historians â€œhave a much harsher viewâ€ of him than others. Then itâ€™s that they â€œhave a less generous view.â€ Then itâ€™s â€œHistorians have a negative view of Nebe and his motivations, despite his participation in the 20 July plot.â€ Coffman is beginning to understand that history is an edit war. Truth, factual and moral, hangs in the balance.

Similar battles over how to remember the past have been raging across society. Do we let the old bronze statues stand in our boulevards, or do we put them in a museum someplace, or do we melt them down? Can there be a â€œheroâ€ who fought for a morally rotten cause? Are qualities like valor and self-sacrifice and tactical brilliance worth admiring anywhere they occur, even if, say, racial supremacism is there too? Some choose to take to the streets. Coffman fights on the terrain most familiar to her, with the weapons she knows best. Not that she would put it that way; sheâ€™s not big on war metaphors.

Several weeks into her new obsession, Coffman realizes that sheâ€™s supposed to fill out her User pageâ€”the Wikipedia equivalent of a profile, where editors broadcast opinions, grudges, achievements, pet peeves. One Saturday night she updates it for the first time. â€œIâ€™m a new editor to Wikipedia,â€ she writes. â€œI enjoy contributing and engaging with other editors.â€

An hour later, past midnight, she adds: â€œMy editing style tends to be bold.â€

Coffman was raised by engineers in the waning days of the Soviet Union. She had what she describes as a â€œculturally privileged upbringingâ€ in Moscow. She went to galleries, museums, the theater. In her neighborhood, she remembers fondly, there was a recycling kiosk that rewarded you with literature. â€œFor this number of kilos of paper you could get these books,â€ she says. â€œClassics: Pushkin, Tolstoy. Reading was encouraged.â€

She wasnâ€™t taught to romanticize the war. â€œThe martial qualities of the veterans were never celebrated,â€ Coffman says. â€œIt wasnâ€™t about the glorious victories, fighters zooming down on enemy ships.â€ Her grandfather, a soil scientist, served in the Red Army as a combat engineer and survived the assault on Leningrad. But in typical fashion, she says, she heard next to nothing about his experiences when she was kid. (For the first time, in response to questions for this article, Coffman asked her father what he knew. She reported back that at one point her grandfather had considered suicide. â€œThe only thing that prevented him from doing this was the thought that he had to get back to his wife and kids,â€ she wrote.)

At university, Coffman majored in computational linguistics, a field that combined her interests in language and science. She was a top student and won a scholarship for business school in the Bay Area. She arrived during the dotcom boom and never left. â€œWhen I moved to the US, I didnâ€™t have this idea of the shining beacon of democracy,â€ she says. But at least she could feel safe. â€œI would walk down the street and the police officer wouldnâ€™t assault me or ask me for a bribe.â€

Coffman, who has broad shoulders under a bob of blond hair, thinks and talks deliberately. She lives in a compact townhouse in a planned community in San Jose, California. The museums and galleries are harder to get to now (â€œI have to drive to San Francisco, find parkingâ€), but she keeps stimulated with books, hobbies, and books about her hobbies. When I visited her at home earlier this year, she walked me past the weight-lifting setup on the ground floor. (She read Starting Strength: Basic Barbell Training for that one. She approves of the book because itâ€™s â€œlike a science manual.â€) Upstairs, I recognized the tall, narrow bookshelf that appears behind her during Zoom calls. It contains dozens of titles that wouldnâ€™t look out of place in a history grad studentâ€™s apartmentâ€”Hitlerâ€™s Generals on Trial. Kiev: 1941. Soldaten: On Fighting, Killing, and Dying. A few others, like In the Company of Women, nod to a career in business.

The Second World War is where Coffman feels most comfortable, but in 2015, she says, she got interested in the US Civil War. That summer, a young white supremacist murdered nine congregants at a Black church in Charleston, South Carolina. The shooting made her realize, she says, that â€œthere was all this other Americaâ€ that lay beyond her experienceâ€”a place deeply scarred by a past she barely understood.

So Coffman did what she always did: She read. And because she happened to be between jobs, she was free to immerse herself in history for long stretches. She learned about the Civil War, the conflict behind so much of the turmoil in the United States. She read about â€œlost causeâ€ ideology, which claims the Confederacy actually fought to preserve high-minded Southern ideals, not specifically the institution of slavery. She brushed up on her knowledge of the Second World War, a struggle more familiar to her.

Maybe the lack of a job, of people to collaborate with, is also what made Wikipedia seem like an attractive pastime. Thatâ€™s what it was supposed to be: another hobby. At first, Coffman stuck to tentative, sporadic suggestions. But then she was making edits nearly every day; there was so much to fix. She liked the siteâ€™s intricate bureaucracyâ€”the guidelines on etiquette and reliable sourcing, the policies on dispute resolution and article deletion, the learned essays and discussion pages that editors cite like case law. â€œWikipedia is very regimented,â€ she says. â€œI am good with instructions.â€

â€œGâ€™day,â€ Peacemaker67 begins his note for K.e. coffman. Itâ€™s late 2015, and he is concerned about recent changes to an article on Wikipedia (â€œWPâ€ for short) about an SS tank division made up of Nordic Nazi volunteers. â€œSorry but there appears to be some sort of misunderstanding about what should be deleted on WP, and I just want to clarify it before this gets too far down the track.â€

Coffman recognizes this editorâ€™s handle. Heâ€™s Australian, and his User page says he served as a peacekeeper in the former Yugoslavia. He is the same person who invited her to join WikiProject Military History, a group where editors can chat, take classes, win plaudits, and work on articles together.

Not for the first time, Coffman has been removing material from the article about the tank division. She thinks itâ€™s full of unsourced fancruft, the Wikipedia word for fawning, excessively detailed descriptions that appeal to a tiny niche of readersâ€”in this case, those thrilled by accounts of battle. The article tells how â€œthe division acquitted itself wellâ€ even against â€œstiffening resistance,â€ how it â€œheld the lineâ€ and earned the â€œgrudging respectâ€ of skeptical commanders. One contributor has used the eyebrow-raising phrase â€œbaptism of fire.â€ Itâ€™s as if the editors donâ€™t see the part lower down the page where a soldier uses the phrase â€œand then we cleaned a Jew hole.â€

The glorifying language, Coffman thinks, is a clear sign that this is historical fan fiction. It elides the horrors of war. If editors want such details to stay on the page, at a minimum they should use a better source than Axis History, a blog whose motto is â€œInformation not shared is lost.â€

The interaction starts out politely enough. â€œIMHO it is good that you are deleting citations from unreliable bloggy sources,â€ Peacemaker67 says. â€œBut just because material is sourced to them doesnâ€™t mean it is wrong.â€

K.e.coffman replies in less than an hour. â€œThank you for your note,â€ she writes. â€œYes, I was surprised about how little I was able to salvage as I was editing the article.â€ She lists 17 bullet-pointed examples of biased language, Nazi glorification, and unreliable claims. â€œWould Wikipedia not be better without such content?â€ she asks.

â€œWell, people are on WP for different reasons,â€ Peacemaker67 replies. â€œI donâ€™t go around deleting stuff because I think it might be dodgy.â€ He cites a page that counsels gradualism in editing, because Wikipedia is a work in progress. â€œArticles have long histories, and there is no WP:DEADLINE,â€ he says.

Coffman cites a different doctrine in response. â€œIâ€™m of the view that thereâ€™s indeed a deadline: Wikipedia:The deadline is now,â€ she writes. â€œWhy perpetuate misinformation when it can be removed, or give legitimacy to glorification while there are already plenty of sites that do that? I believe Wikipediaâ€™s standards to be higher.â€

Peacemaker67â€™s final response, nine minutes later, is curt: â€œIf you take this sort of action on articles on my watchlist, expect to be reverted and asked to provide reliable sources that contradict what is in the article.â€

Like other editors whom Coffman will encounter, Peacemaker67 sees something pernicious in her work. In a recent email, he told me that he considers Coffmanâ€™s approach â€œmost unencyclopaedic and a prime example of what Wikipedia is not (see WP:NOTCENSORED).â€ He went on: â€œWill we apply the same censorship to military history articles on units of the Khmer Rouge? Turkish military units involved in the Armenian Genocide? Rwandan military units involved in the genocide in that country? US cavalry units that massacred Native Americans? Arkanâ€™s Tigers? Where does that end?â€

Coffman finds her next target in the footnotes of the article about the tank division. This oneâ€™s name is Franz Kurowski, and he seems to pop up all over the place. Kurowski served in the Luftwaffe. After the war, he tried his hand at all sorts of popular writing, often with a pseudonym to match: Jason Meeker and Slade Cassidy for his crime fiction and westerns, Johanna Schulz and Gloria Mellina for his chick lit. But his accounts of the Second World War made him famous under his own name. Kurowskiâ€™s stories werenâ€™t subtle. As the German historian Roman TÃ¶ppel writes in a critical essay: â€œThey depict war as a test of fate and partly as adventure. German war crimes are left outâ€”much unlike allied war crimes.â€

To understand this dubious chronicler better, Coffman goes to Google, where she comes upon a book called The Myth of the Eastern Front. It describes how, in the immediate aftermath of the war, characters like Kurowski worked to rehabilitate the image of the German armyâ€”to argue that a few genocidal apples had spoiled the barrel. With a guy like Hitler to pin the blame on, the rest was easy. The so-called â€œmyth of the clean Wehrmachtâ€ took root on both sides of the Atlantic: German society needed to believe that not everyone who wore a gray uniform was evil, and the Americans were courting every anti-Communist ally they could find. Then, in the mid-1990s, a museum exhibit cataloging the crimes of the Nazi-era military traveled throughout Germany. An odd situation emerged: Germans began to speak more honestly about the Wehrmacht than non-Germans did.

When Coffman reads this, something clicks. She is dealing with a poisonous tree here. She shouldnâ€™t be throwing out individual pieces of fruit. She should be chopping it off at the trunk. She starts to pivot from history (the facts themselves) to historiography (the way theyâ€™re gathered). She begins to use Wikipedia to document the false historical narrative, and its purveyors, and then make the fight about dubious sources rather than specific articles.

On Christmas Eve, she returns to Arthur Nebeâ€™s page and makes a one-word addition: â€œHistorians have a uniformly negative view of Nebe and his motives.â€

In the spring of 2016, Coffman goes through hundreds of articles about the winners of various Nazi medals, including one called the Knightâ€™s Cross of the Iron Cross. She removes biased sources and any information based on those sources. When she is done, typically, there is nothing left to the articleâ€”nothing to say about the personâ€”other than the fact that he won an award. She then insists that an award isnâ€™t reason enough for a stand-alone Wikipedia article. Without a reliable source telling your life story, you canâ€™t be notable. Poof. Another Nazi legend bites the dust.

A particularly revered medal winner, or a high-ranking one, might survive Coffmanâ€™s purge. But the results arenâ€™t pretty. When she arrives at Kurt Knispelâ€™s page, it says that he was â€œone of the, if not the, greatest tank ace of all time.â€ His photo shows a young gunner with shaggy blond hair and a goatee. He flashes a smile, unaware that he is doomed.

Unfortunately for Knispel, his reputation rests almost entirely on stories told by Kurowski, as well as an account in the Wehrmachtbericht, the Nazi propaganda broadcast. Coffman strips away the apocryphal stories of action and adventure, like the one that says Knispel was held back from promotions because he assaulted a superior. When sheâ€™s done, the article is reduced to four paragraphs, three of which relate to his death, at age 23, when he was struck by a Soviet tank. Later, someone will leave a short, sad note on the articleâ€™s Talk page: â€œThere used to be a lot of information here about his military career, unconventional attitude to military discipline etc. â€¦ Why has it been deleted?â€

Coffmanâ€™s edits have jumped from 1,400 a month to 5,000. She is entering her most prolific period. She has been filling her User page with study guides and research, but now her tone gets bolder, punchier. The names of the sections go from dry (â€œWaffen-SS revisionismâ€) to cheerfully contemptuous (â€œHigh Moral Fiber Sub-departmentâ€). The page is becoming a sprawling tongue-in-cheek taxonomy of her obsessionâ€”and the parapet from which she taunts her adversaries.

â€œGâ€™day,â€ she reads in a note in the summer of 2016. Itâ€™s Peacemaker67 again, back with one last warning. â€œIâ€™ve noticed that you have been nominating articles on Knightâ€™s Cross of the Iron Cross recipients for deletion, after you have deleted significant amounts of text and possible sources from them,â€ he writes. â€œThat type of behaviour is deplorable, and not appropriate on en WP.â€ (Coffmanâ€™s detractors often imply that she doesnâ€™t fit in on â€œen WP,â€ or English Wikipedia. They often assume that she is a visitor from German Wikipedia, â€œde WP,â€ because of her insistence on holding the Wehrmacht to account.) â€œI suggest you stop,â€ Peacemaker67 concludes. â€œCheers.â€

They go back and forth again. Eventually, Coffman appeals to the broader Wikipedia community to decide who is right about the notability of these medal winners. â€œThe issue appears to be complex, so I would appreciate further input,â€ she writes. The debate hinges on certain policy wordings, along with the question of how to compare military awards from France, the US, Great Britain, and Germany. The WikiProject Military History members are well represented, but Coffman picks up crucial support. A user called MaxRavenclaw objects to the claim that purging Iron Cross winners is a form of â€œvictorâ€™s justiceâ€: â€œYou should know that history is written by the literate, not the victors. You canâ€™t expect anyone to take you seriously when you make such statements.â€

The fight rages across pages for months. In the fall, Peacemaker67 writes that he is â€œfrankly sick to deathâ€ of K.e.coffmanâ€™s â€œongoing campaign.â€ It is â€œdetracting from the enjoyment of the volunteer editors who actually contribute to this encyclopaedia,â€ he writes. A careful reader of his cri de coeur will note that he assumes Coffman to be a man (â€œCommunity norms rule on WP, not his personal viewsâ€). This is a common misimpression among the Military History gang. Coffman never tries to correct it.

After six months of debate, on January 22, 2017, Coffman is vindicated. An administrator leaves a note steeped in Wikipedia reasoning. â€œIn the case of the Knightâ€™s Cross the community has established a consensus,â€ it concludes. â€œSufficient reliable sources are lacking for many recipients.â€ In other words, there should be no presumption that winning a Knightâ€™s Cross of the Iron Cross makes you notable enough for a Wikipedia article. The only thing youâ€™re guaranteed is a one-line spot on a long list of winners.

After the case is settled, Coffman and her more vocal opponents retreat to separate corners. But one bitter-ender, LargelyRecyclable, appears to create a troll account and continues objecting to her changes. She finally takes the user to the Arbitration Committee, English Wikipediaâ€™s version of the Supreme Court.

The panel doesnâ€™t wade into the specifics, writing explicitly that â€œit is not the role of the Arbitration Committee to settle good-faith content disputes among editors.â€ But what it does rule gives Coffman a feeling of support, she says. LargelyRecyclable is banned indefinitely from editing English Wikipedia. The ArbCom also notes that groups like WikiProject Military History â€œdo not have any authority over article content or editor conduct, or any other special powers.â€ They can accuse Coffman of whatever they likeâ€”vandalism, McCarthyism, â€œdeletionist zeal.â€ She has just as much right to edit history as they do.

And few can match her output: 97,000 edits, 3,200 pages created, countless debates argued and won. Today, K.e.coffman is a solid member of English Wikipediaâ€™s editorial eliteâ€”No. 734 out of 121,000, as of this writing. She keeps a watch list with about 2,000 articles on it. A notification pops up next to the listing whenever someone tries to make a change. Thatâ€™s the thing about edit wars: They never end.

But Coffman, of course, avoids martial language. Wikipedia isnâ€™t a battlefield; itâ€™s real estate. â€œYou have to maintain your house,â€ she says. â€œYou have to have a security system.â€

On her User page now, there are sections called â€œNazi fancruftâ€ and â€œApocryphal nicknames.â€ There are lists of apologist sources and right-wing publishers. There is an entire offshoot page called â€œMy allegedly problematic behaviour,â€ where she keeps track of the accusations against herâ€”â€œcampaigning,â€ â€œforum-shopping,â€ â€œnot dropping the stick.â€ She has even given herself an award for all her heroic work: the Vandalâ€™s Cross of Iron Cross with Swords and Diamonds.
